resourceInfo.displayName: L. braziliensis chromosomes sequence and annotation
resourceInfo.description:
Sequence data for Leishmania braziliensis clone M2904 (MHOM/BR/75M2904) were downloaded from GeneDB (sequence and annotated features).
Sequencing of L. braziliensis was conducted by The Sanger Institute pathogen sequencing unit.

resourceInfo.displayName: L. braziliensis chromosomes sequence and annotation
resourceInfo.description:
This resource includes chromosome sequences and annotations for Leishmania braziliensis. Sequence data for Leishmania braziliensis clone M2904 (MHOM/BR/75M2904) were downloaded from GeneDB (sequence and annotated features).


L. (Viannia) braziliensis clone LB2904 (MHOM/BR/75M2904) is a reference strain from Evandro Chagas Institute, Belém, Brazil. This strain was isolated by direct culture from a lesion on the right side of the thorax of a man who had been performing survey work in Serra dos Carajás, Brazilian Amazonia.


The LB2904 clone is infective in hamsters and BALB/c mice and can be genetically transfected and cloned on plates.


Sequencing of L. braziliensis was conducted by The Sanger Institute pathogen sequencing unit.

resourceInfo.displayName: GO Association for L. braziliensis genes

resourceInfo.description:
Background

The Leishmania brazilensis M2903 strain was isolated in 1975 from a cutaneous lesion of a man who contracted the infection in a forested area of Serra dos Carajas, Para State, Brazil (J. Shaw, personal communication; cited in Balanco et al. Parisitology (1998) 116: 103-113).


The WHO strain designation is MHOM/BR/75/M2903. Dr. J. Shaw kindly made this strain available for sequencing, with the assistance of Diane McMahon-Pratt (Yale School of Public Health).


RT-PCR typing with several primer sets shows that this line lacks detectable levels of LRV1 virus. This strain can be readily manipulated genetically and possesses a potent RNAi activity. (Lye, L-F., K. L. Owens, H. Shi, S.M.F. Murta, A.C. Vieira, S.J. Turco, C. Tschudi, E. Ullu, and S.M. Beverley (2010), Retention and loss of RNA interference pathways in Trypanosomatid protozoans, Plos Pathogens 6: e1001161. PMCID: PMC2965760). It is infective in various animal models according to the literature and in work in the Beverley laboratory.


Genomic DNA was made by CsCl/Ethidium bromide density gradient centrifugation to minimize the amount of kinetoplast (mitochondrial) DNA.


Next-generation sequences on the 454 instruments were produced for a draft assembly. Total sequence coverage of 454 instrument reads was ~68X (Fragments 22X, 3Kb PE 28X, 8Kb PE 17X) using a genome size estimate of 40Mb. The combined sequence reads were assembled using the Newbler software (Roche 454). This first draft assembly was referred to as L_brazilensis_M2903_1.0.1. This version has been cleaned of contaminants. The assembly is made up of a total of 4410 scaffolds with an N50 scaffold length of over 737kb (N50 contig length for the 7215 contigs was 17kb). The assembly spans 33Mb.


This work was supported by NIH grants AI29646 and AI 31078 to SMB and by NIH-NHGRI grant 5U54HG00307907 to RKW, Director of The Genome Center at Washington University.


For questions regarding this L_brazilensis_M2903_1.0.1 assembly please contact Dr. Wes Warren, Washington University School of Medicine (wwarren@watson.wustl.edu). Downloads of the sequence data are available via the TriTrypDB genome browser server. Funding for the sequence characterization of the Leishmania brazilensis M2903 genome was provided by the National Human Genome Research Institute (NHGRI), National Institutes of Health (NIH).


Credits

DNA source - Drs. Stephen M. Beverley (beverley@borcim.wustl.edu) & Natalia Akopyants, Department of Molecular Microbiology, Washington University School of Medicine, St Louis, MO.

LRV typing Drs. Lon-Fye Lye and Stephen M. Beverley, Department of Molecular Microbiology, Washington University School of Medicine, St Louis, MO.

Sequencing - The Genome Center, Washington University School of Medicine, St Louis, MO.

Sequence assembly The Genome Center, Washington University School of Medicine, St Louis, MO.

Citation upon use of this assembly in a manuscript

It is requested that users of this Leishmania brazilensis M2903 strain sequence assembly acknowledge Stephen M. Beverley and The Genome Center, Washington University School of Medicine in any publications that result from use of this sequence assembly. Any publications that propose to use whole genome or chromosome data should contact The Genome Center at Washington University (gweinsto@wustl.edu or wwarren@wustl.edu) for the use of pre-publication data. Please refer to the Genome Center Data Use Policy (http://genome.wustl.edu/data/data_use_policy) for further information regarding proper use of data and proper citation.
